content: Legislation to rewrite and reauthorize the Export Administration Act of 1979 (EAA) may be considered in the 111th Congress. Several pieces of legislation in the 110th Congress addressed penalties, enforcement, diversion of goods, and integration of export control data. The EAA controls sensitive dual-use goods and technologies with civilian and military applications, including those that can contribute to the proliferation of nuclear, biological, and chemical weaponry. The EAA has been periodically reauthorized since its original expiration in 1989, with the last extension expiring in August 2001. The Export Administration Act of 1979 (EAA), originally expired in 1989, has been periodically reauthorized, with the last extension expiring in August 2001. The export licensing system under the EAA is continued through the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). The EAA regulates exports of dual-use items with military applications, administered by the Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) in the Department of Commerce. The Export Administration Act (EAA) regulates exports of dual-use items with military applications. The report discusses the evolution of the act, types of controls authorized, export licensing procedures, and issues concerning the maintenance of export controls. It also highlights controlled commodities and debates on technology control, multilateral regimes, and the organization of the export control system. Export controls have been a part of U.S. policy for almost a century, with a shift towards peacetime regulations after WWII. The Export Control Act of 1949 was enacted in response to the new security threats, focusing on the Soviet-Bloc countries. The Act outlined reasons for imposing export controls, including preventing short-supply situations. The Export Control Act of 1949 (P.L. 81-11) established a peacetime export control system to address security threats. It identified three reasons for imposing export controls: short-supply, foreign policy, and national security controls. These controls encompass issues such as regional stability, human rights, anti-terrorism, missile technology, and chemical and biological warfare. National security controls aim to restrict exports that could enhance the military capability of countries threatening U.S. national security.
